message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of minimal pubic hair, suprapubic masses, small vagina, and no visible cervical canal suggest androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS), which is an X-linked recessive disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, which is caused by X-linked recessive inheritance. Autosomal recessive, extra chromosome, and multiple genetic loci are not associated with this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS), which is an X-linked recessive disorder. This means that the mutation causing AIS is located on the X chromosome and affects females more often than males. Male carriers of the mutation do not show any symptoms or signs of the disorder, but their daughters have a 50% chance of inheriting the mutation and developing AIS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s physical exam findings suggest androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS), which is an X-linked recessive disorder. This means that the mutation causing the disorder is located on the X chromosome, and females need to inherit two copies of the mutated gene to express the disorder. Because her husband has children from a previous marriage, it suggests that the infertility is due to the patient’s genetic condition rather than her husband’s fertility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presenting symptoms and physical exam findings suggest Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, which has an X-linked recessive mode of inheritance. The other options do not fit the presentation of this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits signs of Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, which is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and/or vagina. It is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, with females being affected while males are usually unaffected carriers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, which has X-linked recessive inheritance. MRKH syndrome is a genetic condition that affects the development of the female reproductive system, resulting in absent or underdeveloped vagina and uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting the symptoms of Turner syndrome, where one X chromosome is missing or partially missing. Turner syndrome is caused by a mutation on the X chromosome and follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings suggest Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, which is a congenital abnormality that affects females and involves the absence of the vagina and/or uterus. It is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with features of Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, which is characterized by Müllerian duct malformation resulting in absent or underdeveloped uterus and vagina. MRKH syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant or sporadic pattern, so the most likely mode of inheritance is X-linked recessive.
